COlin,

I was also curious, what experiments are those really complicated-
looking networks from?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> There are some example network images generated by SharpNeat at: 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/networks.htm
> 
> There isn't a new software release with this in (yet), these are 
just 
> examples showing how the layout manager places the neurons into 
layers 
> and how connections back into the same or previous layers are 
drawn.
> The networks themselves aren't meant to be good functional 
examples 
> since they seem to have a lot of redundancy, e.g. the xor networks 
> contain a lot of hidden nodes whereas we know that only one or two 
are 
> needed depending on the type of network. What they do show is how 
> networks of varying complexity are drawn, and hence the limits of 
these 
> types of diagram.
> 
> The layout manager basically places the hidden neurons into a 
> rectangular grid that best matches the available space, there is 
no 
> attempt at analysing interconnections to determine which neurons 
should 
> be in which layers, etc.  Inputs and outputs are all drawn in 
their own 
> layer, so for example if there were a lot of  inputs then you 
would see 
> an overcrowded input layer.
> 
> The connections are coloured to indicate their strength using a 
blue-red 
> scale. Optionally I can also vary the width of the connections but 
this 
> seems to clutter up the diagrams that much more.
> 
> Going forward then there will be the able to manipulate the 
networks, 
> drag neurons around and zoom in/out and save/load these as 
annotated xml 
> (hint-xpos/ypos in the saved xml). As I mentioned before I hope to 
> incorporate this stuff into the main exe to show the current best 
> network (and perhaps best of each species?) and also in the 
simulators 
> to show the loaded network in realtime using varying 
neuron/connection 
> colors.
> 
> Colin.
